body:
Hi again

In relation to the previous post it seems a great idea to change the link so that it can reach all the amazing fandoms that are in GOT so that we can all help.

I want to make it clear that it is not my link and I have already spoken with the person who passed me the message and link to try to change it.

tags: this is a further entry into the series I have unofficially named
jon snow continues to treat women right
(this is for the free choice prompt for day 7 but I'm posting it a little early because I can't tomorrow)
summary: “You know, your aunt said you were a bit of a disaster,” Missandei says, as Jon lies on his yoga mat looking wrecked after the...
caption:
“You know, your aunt said you were a bit of a disaster,” Missandei says, as Jon lies on his yoga mat looking wrecked after the advanced yoga class they’ve just taken under the pagoda at the island resort Dany has hired out for her wedding to Khal Drogo.

“Well she had only nice things to say about you,” he says, groaning as he sits up on his elbows. He’s fit, Jon, in a brooding, messy sort of way, and she can tell he spends lots of time in the gym, but he’s an idiot to have jumped straight into an advanced class after admitting that he had never done any yoga before. “I don’t want you to think I’m not flexible,” he says, twisting his back to make it pop, grunting at the stretch, biceps straining at his white t-shirt.

OK, so Jon is really fit, Missandei admits, and the sound of that grunt certainly conjures up all sorts of interesting images, “I mean, you’re not flexible,” she says, “that’s just a statement of fact, it’s not a value judgement.”

- if we’re talking body by framboise

|| for day 7 of @asoiafrarepairs week ||

summary: Hi! You might have seen that the Jonsa fandom has raised 1k dollars for charity women4women UK and the creator seems more than...
body:
Let’s all help!!

Hi! You might have seen that the Jonsa fandom has raised 1k dollars for charity women4women UK and the creator seems more than happy at the possibility of us doing sth similar, and I think we should! so here’s the link https://www.justgiving.com/fundraising/joneryshelpswomen


If you could pass it on to the friends in the fandom or post this in your tumblr, I’t would help a lot!

summary: I know we talk and think a lot about how long Dany sat at Jon’s bedside, but for some reason it only just occurred to me that...
body: I know we talk and think a lot about how long Dany sat at Jon’s bedside, but for some reason it only just occurred to me that she probably wasn’t just sitting idly by doing nothing. I don’t think it’s outside of the realm of possibilities to think that she might have helped tend to his injuries. Maybe she applied ointments or helped clean him off. Maybe she told him stories while he was knocked out…

reblog.comment: I know we talk and think a lot about how long Dany sat at Jon’s bedside, but for some reason it only just occurred to me that she probably wasn’t just sitting idly by doing nothing. I don’t think it’s outside of the realm of possibilities to think that she might have helped tend to his injuries. Maybe she applied ointments or helped clean him off. Maybe she told him stories while he was knocked out…

summary: Do you think Ned actually loved Jon, or just loved his sister and wanted to express that love by following through on his dying...
question: Do you think Ned actually loved Jon, or just loved his sister and wanted to express that love by following through on his dying promise?
answer:
Well - yes, Ned loved Lyanna and part of the reason we can tell is his commitment to the promise he made her. That doesn’t mean Ned didn’t love Jon in his own right, which he certainly did.

Going to put this under a cut for length.

Let’s start with the fact that Ned named Jon Snow after Jon Arryn. That’s an indicator and a public announcement of Ned’s regard for the kid right there. On the first level, the kid’s named for the Lord of the Vale and someone Ned cared for deeply, that’s a simple mark of affection and regard. On the next level, by giving Jon Snow the name of Ned’s “second father,” who he loves as a father despite the lack of the actual blood relationship, so Ned indicates that he loves Jon Snow as a son, again despite the lack of the actual blood relationship.

Then there’s what we see in Bran III, ADWD.

Lord Eddard seemed much younger this time. His hair was brown, with no hint of grey in it, his head bowed. “… let them grow up close as brothers, with only love between them,” he prayed, “and let my lady wife find it in her heart to forgive …”

Context suggests that Ned’s praying for Jon’s happiness and welcome into the family. We see from Jon’s PoV that Ned was unable to protect Jon from everything that flowed from his bastard status; we can also see from various other PoVs that Ned did his best. Catelyn and Theon both note this. One of the most poignant examples is in the very first chapter proper of the series.

“Lord Stark,” Jon said. It was strange to hear him call Father that, so formal. Bran looked at him with desperate hope. “There are five pups,” he told Father. “Three male, two female.” 

“What of it, Jon?”

“You have five trueborn children,” Jon said. “Three sons, two daughters. The direwolf is the sigil of your House. Your children were meant to have these pups, my lord.”

Bran saw his father’s face change, saw the other men exchange glances. He loved Jon with all his heart at that moment. Even at seven, Bran understood what his brother had done. The count had come right only because Jon had omitted himself. He had included the girls, included even Rickon, the baby, but not the bastard who bore the surname Snow, the name that custom decreed be given to all those in the north unlucky enough to be born with no name of their own.

Their father understood as well. “You want no pup for yourself, Jon?” he asked softly.

- Bran I, AGoT

Ned understands that symbolically excluding himself from a count of Ned’s children hurts Jon, and he’s not keen on the idea. Over in Catelyn’s PoV, we see Ned get angry at the prospect of Catelyn kicking Jon out of the house.

The look Ned gave her was anguished. “You know I cannot take him south. There will be no place for him at court. A boy with a bastard’s name… you know what they will say of him. He will be shunned.”

Catelyn armored her heart against the mute appeal in her husband’s eyes. “They say your friend Robert has fathered a dozen bastards himself.”

“And none of them has ever been seen at court!” Ned blazed. “The Lannister woman has seen to that. How can you be so damnably cruel, Catelyn? He is only a boy. He-”

His fury was on him. He might have said more, and worse, but Maester Luwin cut in.

- Catelyn II, AGoT

He’s actually angry. There’s more going on here than Catelyn knows, since while Ned could quite possibly find a place for his bastard son at court, there’s no way in hell Ned’s bringing Rhaegar Targaryen’s biological son to the Red Keep and putting him in the proximity of Robert or the Lannisters. Nevertheless, Ned’s anger reflects his commitment to Jon’s welfare, and the fact that he argues using Jon’s welfare as the reason behind his actions doesn’t make Catelyn bat an eyelid with how unusual this is.

Ironically, one of the stronger bits of evidence that Jon isn’t Ned’s son also goes to show Ned’s paternal love for him.

Ned thought, if it came to that, the life of some child I did not know, against Robb and Sansa and Arya and Bran and Rickon, what would I do? Even more so, what would Catelyn do, if it were Jon’s life, against the children of her body? He did not know. He prayed he never would.

- Eddard XII, AGoT

No, Ned does not list Jon amongst his children. However, his questions about what Catelyn would do if it were Jon’s life demonstrate that, though he might not think of Jon as his son, he would act as though Jon were his son. The distinction between Ned’s hypothetical actions and Catelyn’s hypothetical actions is necessary - because Ned loves Jon as much as he loves his biological children.

This is not to say that Ned was a perfect parent to Jon. Jon certainly is under the impression that Ned’s ashamed of both him and his mother. This sense of shame is part and parcel of a bastard’s existence. As Littlefinger tells Sansa,

“Alayne is pretty.” Sansa hoped she would remember. “But couldn’t I be the trueborn daughter of some knight in your service? Perhaps he died gallantly in the battle, and …”

“I have no gallant knights in my service, Alayne. Such a tale would draw unwanted questions as a corpse draws crows. It is rude to pry into the origins of a man’s natural children, however.“ 

- Sansa VI, ASoS

Ned isn’t ashamed of Jon himself, but nor does he feel himself able to correct this misconception. (After all, if it’s not shame holding Ned’s tongue, what reason does he have to be so closemouthed about Jon’s parentage?) When Ned himself is in the black cells, then he feels shame.

The thought of Jon filled Ned with a sense of shame, and a sorrow too deep for words. If only he could see the boy again, sit and talk with him…

- Eddard XV, AGoT

This shame comes from his awareness of how he’s failed Jon as a parent. Specifically, the addition of Ned’s desire to talk to Jon (and, the implication is, to tell him about his mother) would indicate his awareness of how Ned’s secrecy has hurt Jon, serious regret for that fact, and a desire to correct it.

While the situation surrounding Jon’s adoption is complicated and painful, and for more than just Ned, it’s still clear that Ned did his level best as a parent for Jon’s own sake, not just Lyanna’s. He is Jon’s father in every sense but the biological one. It’s a relationship of love.

Their father understood as well. “You want no pup for yourself, Jon?” he asked softly.

Ned understands that symbolically excluding himself from a count of Ned’s children hurts Jon, and he’s not keen on the idea. Over in Catelyn’s PoV, we see Ned get angry at the prospect of Catelyn kicking Jon out of the house.

The look Ned gave her was anguished. “You know I cannot take him south. There will be no place for him at court. A boy with a bastard’s name… you know what they will say of him. He will be shunned.”

Catelyn armored her heart against the mute appeal in her husband’s eyes. “They say your friend Robert has fathered a dozen bastards himself.”

“And none of them has ever been seen at court!” Ned blazed. “The Lannister woman has seen to that. How can you be so damnably cruel, Catelyn? He is only a boy. He-”

His fury was on him. He might have said more, and worse, but Maester Luwin cut in.

- Catelyn II, AGoT

He’s actually angry. There’s more going on here than Catelyn knows, since while Ned could quite possibly find a place for his bastard son at court, there’s no way in hell Ned’s bringing Rhaegar Targaryen’s biological son to the Red Keep and putting him in the proximity of Robert or the Lannisters. Nevertheless, Ned’s anger reflects his commitment to Jon’s welfare, and the fact that he argues using Jon’s welfare as the reason behind his actions doesn’t make Catelyn bat an eyelid with how unusual this is.

Ironically, one of the stronger bits of evidence that Jon isn’t Ned’s son also goes to show Ned’s paternal love for him.

Ned thought, if it came to that, the life of some child I did not know, against Robb and Sansa and Arya and Bran and Rickon, what would I do? Even more so, what would Catelyn do, if it were Jon’s life, against the children of her body? He did not know. He prayed he never would.

- Eddard XII, AGoT

No, Ned does not list Jon amongst his children. However, his questions about what Catelyn would do if it were Jon’s life demonstrate that, though he might not think of Jon as his son, he would act as though Jon were his son. The distinction between Ned’s hypothetical actions and Catelyn’s hypothetical actions is necessary - because Ned loves Jon as much as he loves his biological children.

This is not to say that Ned was a perfect parent to Jon. Jon certainly is under the impression that Ned’s ashamed of both him and his mother. This sense of shame is part and parcel of a bastard’s existence. As Littlefinger tells Sansa,

“Alayne is pretty.” Sansa hoped she would remember. “But couldn’t I be the trueborn daughter of some knight in your service? Perhaps he died gallantly in the battle, and …”

“I have no gallant knights in my service, Alayne. Such a tale would draw unwanted questions as a corpse draws crows. It is rude to pry into the origins of a man’s natural children, however.“ 

- Sansa VI, ASoS

Ned isn’t ashamed of Jon himself, but nor does he feel himself able to correct this misconception. (After all, if it’s not shame holding Ned’s tongue, what reason does he have to be so closemouthed about Jon’s parentage?) When Ned himself is in the black cells, then he feels shame.

The thought of Jon filled Ned with a sense of shame, and a sorrow too deep for words. If only he could see the boy again, sit and talk with him…

- Eddard XV, AGoT

This shame comes from his awareness of how he’s failed Jon as a parent. Specifically, the addition of Ned’s desire to talk to Jon (and, the implication is, to tell him about his mother) would indicate his awareness of how Ned’s secrecy has hurt Jon, serious regret for that fact, and a desire to correct it.

While the situation surrounding Jon’s adoption is complicated and painful, and for more than just Ned, it’s still clear that Ned did his level best as a parent for Jon’s own sake, not just Lyanna’s. He is Jon’s father in every sense but the biological one. It’s a relationship of love.
trail.content:
Well - yes, Ned loved Lyanna and part of the reason we can tell is his commitment to the promise he made her. That doesn’t mean Ned didn’t love Jon in his own right, which he certainly did.

Going to put this under a cut for length.

Let’s start with the fact that Ned named Jon Snow after Jon Arryn. That’s an indicator and a public announcement of Ned’s regard for the kid right there. On the first level, the kid’s named for the Lord of the Vale and someone Ned cared for deeply, that’s a simple mark of affection and regard. On the next level, by giving Jon Snow the name of Ned’s “second father,” who he loves as a father despite the lack of the actual blood relationship, so Ned indicates that he loves Jon Snow as a son, again despite the lack of the actual blood relationship.

Then there’s what we see in Bran III, ADWD.

Lord Eddard seemed much younger this time. His hair was brown, with no hint of grey in it, his head bowed. “… let them grow up close as brothers, with only love between them,” he prayed, “and let my lady wife find it in her heart to forgive …”

Context suggests that Ned’s praying for Jon’s happiness and welcome into the family. We see from Jon’s PoV that Ned was unable to protect Jon from everything that flowed from his bastard status; we can also see from various other PoVs that Ned did his best. Catelyn and Theon both note this. One of the most poignant examples is in the very first chapter proper of the series.

“Lord Stark,” Jon said. It was strange to hear him call Father that, so formal. Bran looked at him with desperate hope. “There are five pups,” he told Father. “Three male, two female.” 

“What of it, Jon?”

“You have five trueborn children,” Jon said. “Three sons, two daughters. The direwolf is the sigil of your House. Your children were meant to have these pups, my lord.”

Bran saw his father’s face change, saw the other men exchange glances. He loved Jon with all his heart at that moment. Even at seven, Bran understood what his brother had done. The count had come right only because Jon had omitted himself. He had included the girls, included even Rickon, the baby, but not the bastard who bore the surname Snow, the name that custom decreed be given to all those in the north unlucky enough to be born with no name of their own.

Their father understood as well. “You want no pup for yourself, Jon?” he asked softly.

- Bran I, AGoT

Ned understands that symbolically excluding himself from a count of Ned’s children hurts Jon, and he’s not keen on the idea. Over in Catelyn’s PoV, we see Ned get angry at the prospect of Catelyn kicking Jon out of the house.

The look Ned gave her was anguished. “You know I cannot take him south. There will be no place for him at court. A boy with a bastard’s name… you know what they will say of him. He will be shunned.”

Catelyn armored her heart against the mute appeal in her husband’s eyes. “They say your friend Robert has fathered a dozen bastards himself.”

“And none of them has ever been seen at court!” Ned blazed. “The Lannister woman has seen to that. How can you be so damnably cruel, Catelyn? He is only a boy. He-”

His fury was on him. He might have said more, and worse, but Maester Luwin cut in.

- Catelyn II, AGoT

He’s actually angry. There’s more going on here than Catelyn knows, since while Ned could quite possibly find a place for his bastard son at court, there’s no way in hell Ned’s bringing Rhaegar Targaryen’s biological son to the Red Keep and putting him in the proximity of Robert or the Lannisters. Nevertheless, Ned’s anger reflects his commitment to Jon’s welfare, and the fact that he argues using Jon’s welfare as the reason behind his actions doesn’t make Catelyn bat an eyelid with how unusual this is.

Ironically, one of the stronger bits of evidence that Jon isn’t Ned’s son also goes to show Ned’s paternal love for him.

Ned thought, if it came to that, the life of some child I did not know, against Robb and Sansa and Arya and Bran and Rickon, what would I do? Even more so, what would Catelyn do, if it were Jon’s life, against the children of her body? He did not know. He prayed he never would.

- Eddard XII, AGoT

No, Ned does not list Jon amongst his children. However, his questions about what Catelyn would do if it were Jon’s life demonstrate that, though he might not think of Jon as his son, he would act as though Jon were his son. The distinction between Ned’s hypothetical actions and Catelyn’s hypothetical actions is necessary - because Ned loves Jon as much as he loves his biological children.

This is not to say that Ned was a perfect parent to Jon. Jon certainly is under the impression that Ned’s ashamed of both him and his mother. This sense of shame is part and parcel of a bastard’s existence. As Littlefinger tells Sansa,

“Alayne is pretty.” Sansa hoped she would remember. “But couldn’t I be the trueborn daughter of some knight in your service? Perhaps he died gallantly in the battle, and …”

“I have no gallant knights in my service, Alayne. Such a tale would draw unwanted questions as a corpse draws crows. It is rude to pry into the origins of a man’s natural children, however.“ 

- Sansa VI, ASoS

Ned isn’t ashamed of Jon himself, but nor does he feel himself able to correct this misconception. (After all, if it’s not shame holding Ned’s tongue, what reason does he have to be so closemouthed about Jon’s parentage?) When Ned himself is in the black cells, then he feels shame.

The thought of Jon filled Ned with a sense of shame, and a sorrow too deep for words. If only he could see the boy again, sit and talk with him…

This shame comes from his awareness of how he’s failed Jon as a parent. Specifically, the addition of Ned’s desire to talk to Jon (and, the implication is, to tell him about his mother) would indicate his awareness of how Ned’s secrecy has hurt Jon, serious regret for that fact, and a desire to correct it.

While the situation surrounding Jon’s adoption is complicated and painful, and for more than just Ned, it’s still clear that Ned did his level best as a parent for Jon’s own sake, not just Lyanna’s. He is Jon’s father in every sense but the biological one. It’s a relationship of love.
trail.content_abstract:
Well - yes, Ned loved Lyanna and part of the reason we can tell is his commitment to the promise he made her. That doesn’t mean Ned didn’t love Jon in his own right, which he certainly did.

Going to put this under a cut for length.

Tyrion: Are you interested in our Queen?
Jon Snow: I’m not... Not interested.
Davos: Wow, Jon. Coming from you that’s like a declaration of love.

title: Jonerys Vampire AU: Part 58
body: Part 58: Jon and Daenerys prepare to leave while also enjoying their time together. They draw closer as some hard topics are discussed. AN: I have an out of town friend visiting tomorrow, I will not be updating. Thank you for understanding! 💗#jonerys Image credit to @jonerystargaryensfan 😘♥️

blog.name: mollyraesly
blog.title: Thank You For Being Here Today

body:
Time with Wolves — Chapter 8

Sansa didn’t go back to the wolf reservation for over two months. Instead, she made plans with Mya and Myranda, went to drama practice to help with costumes, and cheered Arya on at her fencing competitions.


When she did go back, it was her father who offered to drive her. They went on a Sunday afternoon, and Arya tagged along, as well.


Arya chattered on about the highlights from her last fencing match and what to expect in her next competition from the back seat. Sansa stayed quiet, lost in thought, trying to chase away her sad feelings and growing anxiety. When they arrived at the reservation, Arya disappeared within the first ten seconds, off to find Nymeria.


Ned wrapped his arm around Sansa. “Why don’t you show me your pup?”


Sansa gave him a smile and led the way. When they reached the pen, she spotted Ghost, who seemed to have grown over double in size since she’d last seen him. “He’s not really a pup anymore,” she observed.


“Ned! Is that you? How are you doing, old friend?”


Sansa watched as Mr. Mormont embraces her father and slapped him on the back.


“Finally come to see how your money’s being used, eh?”


Ned laughed. “Trust me, these checks I am happy to write, Mormont. Tell me how this beast is getting on.”


“Your girl has a better idea than me,” Mormont told him, with his eyes on Sansa. “Though I haven’t seen her in a while. Ghost has missed you, Sansa. Both you and Jon. I’ve missed you, too, if I’m being honest. It was always nice to see you kids. Not many folk who are so caring around the wolves as you. Not many visitors who go through the trouble of making an old bear Christmas presents neither.”


Sansa gave her best attempt at a smile. “I missed you both too.” She walked into the pen, and Ghost all but tackled her. Sansa crouched down to rub behind his ears. She threw her arms around his warm fur, and held him close. “Oh, I missed you, my sweet boy.”


Ned and Mormont continued to talk as Sansa scratched Ghost’s belly and brushed his coat, until Mormont had to go check on another wolf and Ned joined them. He ran his fingers through Ghost’s fur.


They were quiet for a few minutes, petting Ghost and laughing at his lolling tongue.


“He’s a loyal beast,” Ned said softly. “When Lady died, you wouldn’t go near wolves for months. Just the mention of them made you cry. I felt like it was my fault for bringing you here, only to have it bring you so much pain.”


“It wasn’t your fault, Dad,” Sansa told him, her eyes glistening. “Lady was sick.” And it was horrible when she died, like a part of Sansa had died with her. But somehow she survived it, and maybe Lady’s spirit stayed with her—and help her survive now. “I’m glad I got to spend time with her when I did.”


Ned wrapped his arm around her. “I don’t need to know all the details about what happened between you and Jon. I know that the two of you developed a bond, and I know you’ve seemed sad ever since you stopped coming here with him. But I just want you to know, you don’t need Jon to spend time with wolves, Sansa. They’ll always be a part of who you are.” He kissed the crown of her head.


“D—do you think we could come back next week?”


“Sure.”



They visited Ghost together regularly, though not on any fixed day, given her Dad’s duties at work, their family’s busy schedule, and Sansa’s own responsibilities.


A couple of months later, fitting in a visit to the reservation with her dad was starting to feel like part of the routine—as was not seeing Jon.


He hadn’t disappeared completely. She still saw him sometimes at school and a couple of times around town. He even swung by the house to meet Robb, though he never stayed for dinner anymore. He was always polite, always said hello. But their interactions were stilted, as though the months of sitting in his car together every week had never happened.


Sansa would be lying to herself if she said that she’d forgotten a moment of that time. It hurt deeply that he seemed so keen on creating a distance between them. But she’d already cried her tears. And there was nothing to be gained by dwelling on whatever it was they shared now that it was over.


She tried not to think too much on Jon, but some days it felt like she was just waiting to see a glimpse of his face or hear someone mention his name.


One night after dinner, Sansa took extra time drying the dishes so she could eavesdrop on a conversation Robb and Theon were having in the other room. As Jon no longer came round for dinner, Theon was taking his place—a poor consolation prize, Sansa felt. Theon wasn’t such a bad guy, but he was crass and a giant perv. She could hear him describing some girl in graphic detail.


Ordinarily, Sansa would try to tune Theon out when he did this, but she’d heard him mention Jon’s name. So instead she strained her ears as hard as she could.


“Are you sure she’s 21?”


“Yeah, man! I bet she’d buy us some booze if we paid her.”


“But why would she be hanging out with Jon if she’s 21?”


“I told you. He said they met at those meetings he goes to for the army.”


Sansa didn’t realize Jon had told Robb or Theon about his plans. She supposed that meant he must have decided to really do it. The revelation made her drop her dish towel, and in her haste to pick it up, Sansa missed whatever Robb had replied.


Theon was speaking again when she listened in again. “You should have seen her, Robb. Gods, Jon’s such a lucky bastard.”


“Yeah, I’ll believe it when I meet her. What’d you say her name was again?”


“Ygritte.”

Ned laughed. “Trust me, these checks I am happy to write, Mormont. Tell me how this beast is getting on.”


“Your girl has a better idea than me,” Mormont told him, with his eyes on Sansa. “Though I haven’t seen her in a while. Ghost has missed you, Sansa. Both you and Jon. I’ve missed you, too, if I’m being honest. It was always nice to see you kids. Not many folk who are so caring around the wolves as you. Not many visitors who go through the trouble of making an old bear Christmas presents neither.”


Sansa gave her best attempt at a smile. “I missed you both too.” She walked into the pen, and Ghost all but tackled her. Sansa crouched down to rub behind his ears. She threw her arms around his warm fur, and held him close. “Oh, I missed you, my sweet boy.”


Ned and Mormont continued to talk as Sansa scratched Ghost’s belly and brushed his coat, until Mormont had to go check on another wolf and Ned joined them. He ran his fingers through Ghost’s fur.


They were quiet for a few minutes, petting Ghost and laughing at his lolling tongue.


“He’s a loyal beast,” Ned said softly. “When Lady died, you wouldn’t go near wolves for months. Just the mention of them made you cry. I felt like it was my fault for bringing you here, only to have it bring you so much pain.”


“It wasn’t your fault, Dad,” Sansa told him, her eyes glistening. “Lady was sick.” And it was horrible when she died, like a part of Sansa had died with her. But somehow she survived it, and maybe Lady’s spirit stayed with her—and help her survive now. “I’m glad I got to spend time with her when I did.”


Ned wrapped his arm around her. “I don’t need to know all the details about what happened between you and Jon. I know that the two of you developed a bond, and I know you’ve seemed sad ever since you stopped coming here with him. But I just want you to know, you don’t need Jon to spend time with wolves, Sansa. They’ll always be a part of who you are.” He kissed the crown of her head.


“D—do you think we could come back next week?”


“Sure.”



They visited Ghost together regularly, though not on any fixed day, given her Dad’s duties at work, their family’s busy schedule, and Sansa’s own responsibilities.


A couple of months later, fitting in a visit to the reservation with her dad was starting to feel like part of the routine—as was not seeing Jon.


He hadn’t disappeared completely. She still saw him sometimes at school and a couple of times around town. He even swung by the house to meet Robb, though he never stayed for dinner anymore. He was always polite, always said hello. But their interactions were stilted, as though the months of sitting in his car together every week had never happened.


Sansa would be lying to herself if she said that she’d forgotten a moment of that time. It hurt deeply that he seemed so keen on creating a distance between them. But she’d already cried her tears. And there was nothing to be gained by dwelling on whatever it was they shared now that it was over.


She tried not to think too much on Jon, but some days it felt like she was just waiting to see a glimpse of his face or hear someone mention his name.


One night after dinner, Sansa took extra time drying the dishes so she could eavesdrop on a conversation Robb and Theon were having in the other room. As Jon no longer came round for dinner, Theon was taking his place—a poor consolation prize, Sansa felt. Theon wasn’t such a bad guy, but he was crass and a giant perv. She could hear him describing some girl in graphic detail.


Ordinarily, Sansa would try to tune Theon out when he did this, but she’d heard him mention Jon’s name. So instead she strained her ears as hard as she could.


“Are you sure she’s 21?”


“Yeah, man! I bet she’d buy us some booze if we paid her.”


“But why would she be hanging out with Jon if she’s 21?”


“I told you. He said they met at those meetings he goes to for the army.”


Sansa didn’t realize Jon had told Robb or Theon about his plans. She supposed that meant he must have decided to really do it. The revelation made her drop her dish towel, and in her haste to pick it up, Sansa missed whatever Robb had replied.


Theon was speaking again when she listened in again. “You should have seen her, Robb. Gods, Jon’s such a lucky bastard.”


“Yeah, I’ll believe it when I meet her. What’d you say her name was again?”


“Ygritte.”
trail.content:
Time with Wolves — Chapter 8

Sansa didn’t go back to the wolf reservation for over two months. Instead, she made plans with Mya and Myranda, went to drama practice to help with costumes, and cheered Arya on at her fencing competitions.


When she did go back, it was her father who offered to drive her. They went on a Sunday afternoon, and Arya tagged along, as well.


Arya chattered on about the highlights from her last fencing match and what to expect in her next competition from the back seat. Sansa stayed quiet, lost in thought, trying to chase away her sad feelings and growing anxiety. When they arrived at the reservation, Arya disappeared within the first ten seconds, off to find Nymeria.


Ned wrapped his arm around Sansa. “Why don’t you show me your pup?”


Sansa gave him a smile and led the way. When they reached the pen, she spotted Ghost, who seemed to have grown over double in size since she’d last seen him. “He’s not really a pup anymore,” she observed.


“Ned! Is that you? How are you doing, old friend?”


Sansa watched as Mr. Mormont embraces her father and slapped him on the back.


“Finally come to see how your money’s being used, eh?”


Ned laughed. “Trust me, these checks I am happy to write, Mormont. Tell me how this beast is getting on.”


“Your girl has a better idea than me,” Mormont told him, with his eyes on Sansa. “Though I haven’t seen her in a while. Ghost has missed you, Sansa. Both you and Jon. I’ve missed you, too, if I’m being honest. It was always nice to see you kids. Not many folk who are so caring around the wolves as you. Not many visitors who go through the trouble of making an old bear Christmas presents neither.”


Sansa gave her best attempt at a smile. “I missed you both too.” She walked into the pen, and Ghost all but tackled her. Sansa crouched down to rub behind his ears. She threw her arms around his warm fur, and held him close. “Oh, I missed you, my sweet boy.”


Ned and Mormont continued to talk as Sansa scratched Ghost’s belly and brushed his coat, until Mormont had to go check on another wolf and Ned joined them. He ran his fingers through Ghost’s fur.


They were quiet for a few minutes, petting Ghost and laughing at his lolling tongue.


“He’s a loyal beast,” Ned said softly. “When Lady died, you wouldn’t go near wolves for months. Just the mention of them made you cry. I felt like it was my fault for bringing you here, only to have it bring you so much pain.”


“It wasn’t your fault, Dad,” Sansa told him, her eyes glistening. “Lady was sick.” And it was horrible when she died, like a part of Sansa had died with her. But somehow she survived it, and maybe Lady’s spirit stayed with her—and help her survive now. “I’m glad I got to spend time with her when I did.”


Ned wrapped his arm around her. “I don’t need to know all the details about what happened between you and Jon. I know that the two of you developed a bond, and I know you’ve seemed sad ever since you stopped coming here with him. But I just want you to know, you don’t need Jon to spend time with wolves, Sansa. They’ll always be a part of who you are.” He kissed the crown of her head.


“D—do you think we could come back next week?”


“Sure.”



They visited Ghost together regularly, though not on any fixed day, given her Dad’s duties at work, their family’s busy schedule, and Sansa’s own responsibilities.


A couple of months later, fitting in a visit to the reservation with her dad was starting to feel like part of the routine—as was not seeing Jon.


He hadn’t disappeared completely. She still saw him sometimes at school and a couple of times around town. He even swung by the house to meet Robb, though he never stayed for dinner anymore. He was always polite, always said hello. But their interactions were stilted, as though the months of sitting in his car together every week had never happened.


Sansa would be lying to herself if she said that she’d forgotten a moment of that time. It hurt deeply that he seemed so keen on creating a distance between them. But she’d already cried her tears. And there was nothing to be gained by dwelling on whatever it was they shared now that it was over.


She tried not to think too much on Jon, but some days it felt like she was just waiting to see a glimpse of his face or hear someone mention his name.


One night after dinner, Sansa took extra time drying the dishes so she could eavesdrop on a conversation Robb and Theon were having in the other room. As Jon no longer came round for dinner, Theon was taking his place—a poor consolation prize, Sansa felt. Theon wasn’t such a bad guy, but he was crass and a giant perv. She could hear him describing some girl in graphic detail.


Ordinarily, Sansa would try to tune Theon out when he did this, but she’d heard him mention Jon’s name. So instead she strained her ears as hard as she could.


“Are you sure she’s 21?”


“Yeah, man! I bet she’d buy us some booze if we paid her.”


“But why would she be hanging out with Jon if she’s 21?”


“I told you. He said they met at those meetings he goes to for the army.”


Sansa didn’t realize Jon had told Robb or Theon about his plans. She supposed that meant he must have decided to really do it. The revelation made her drop her dish towel, and in her haste to pick it up, Sansa missed whatever Robb had replied.


Theon was speaking again when she listened in again. “You should have seen her, Robb. Gods, Jon’s such a lucky bastard.”


“Yeah, I’ll believe it when I meet her. What’d you say her name was again?”


“Ygritte.”
